It depends...On all of the 6400 Series telephones except the 6416D+M and 6424D+M, the headset connection consists of a headpiece and modular base unit.  The handset plugs into the modular base unit, the headset with A10 Connector plugs into the modular base unit as well.    If you have the 6416D+M and 6424D+M sets, there is a jack provided for ONLY the headset. On these sets, the headset can either be connected with an adapter cord (the Plantronics A10 Connector) to the Headset jack on the back of the telephone or connected to a modular base unit which then plugs into the Headset jack.    Refer to the manual for diagrams: http://www.beatriceco.com/bti/porticus/bell/pdf/bsp/555230739 avaya  6408d+ users guide.pdf

item_name: Skullcandy SLYR Gaming Headset, Black/Yellow (SMSLFY-207)

answers.answer_text: You would need some kind of mixer to get it to work. Two audio signals going to one set of speakers will only play whichever is more powerful. You would also need to make sure the splitter will carry the microphone signal. Most splitters only account for stereo output, not for microphone input. If you set it up so the Xbox is only using the the microphone it could work. So the input would use you iPod to play music while the mic is going to the Xbox. The Slyr uses a USB for the mic input and an RCA red and white for stereo input. So you could plug the iPod into the RCAs with an adaptor and the USB into the Xbox. You would have to test it to verify though.

answers.answer_text: Please check your ps4 settings. Steps: 1. Open Device Manager (Right Click on the Start Button and select Device Manager)  2. Click on Sound, Video and Game Controllers to drop down a list of audio software  3. Right click on the name of your audio driver and choose Update Driver Software  4. Select Browse my computer, then Let Me Pick from a list of device drivers  5. From the list of drivers, choose   "High Definition Audio Device " "  6. Install the driver  7. Restart"

question_text: Is this headset noise cancelling?
bullet_point1: Plantronics Blackwire headset.
bullet_point2: Professional grade wideband audio optimized for PC communication environments where frequent softphone conference calls take place.
bullet_point3: Noise-canceling microphone limits outside noise interruptions, ensuring excellent audio quality and easing listener fatigue.
bullet_point4: Echo cancellation for full-duplex speakerphones when both the microphone and speaker are on at the same time.
bullet_point5: We only accept return within 115 days.
product_description: Hi-Fi stereo sound ensures audio quality for calls and multimedia applications like music, video conferencing, etc. (C620). Call controls include call/answer/end button for easy call management. Volume adjustment with +/. and mute button simplifies operation. Soft ear cushions, and flexible headband adjusts for the perfect fit and all day comfort. QuickAdjust boom offers an adjustable boom angle, and microphone-to-mouth distance for optimal voice transmission. SoundGuard protects hearing from loud sound spikes by limiting call volume at 118db. Choose total-focus sound reduction (C620 binaural design) or converse easily with co-workers while wearing the headset (C610 monaural design). Ideal for frequent users of PC audio, conference calls, webinars, video conferencing and collaboration. Optimized for Microsoft Office Communicator 2007. Standard version supports leading softphone vendors  Avaya, Cisco, IBM and more. Backed by Plantronics global service and support.
item_name: Plantronics Blackwire C620

answers.answer_text: Model C620 has noise cancelling built in (binaural design).  Model C610 is the same thing but does not have noise cancelling built in (monaural design).  My experience with noise cancelling headphones is that they work very effectively at blocking consistent noise like the sound of the jet engine on an airplane or the sound of the office air conditioner.  However sounds that not consistent (like a conversation carried on by nearby co-workers) is not blocked and sometimes seems to be amplified because all the other consistent noise has been blocked.  I learned this using my Bose noise cancelling headphones.  When wearing them in the office, I could hear conversations on the other side of the office that I could not hear when taking the headphones off.  This has never been much of an issue for me wearing the Plantronics C620 headset because the speakers are small enough they fit ON you ear not OVER your ear (completely covering) like the Bose.  Because of this you can still hear some background noise even with the noise cancelling feature on.

The headset has a stated feature of noise cancellation and in my nearly daily use I have found that to be a true claim.  Aside from the better than average quality sound (stereo no less), the outside noise from my very active office area is dampened by the sound of music I listen to through them when I am not on a conference call.
Yes, but the key is to adjust the System settings for the speaker and microphone.

Hello, the Blackwire C620 provides passive noise cancellation due to the design of the ear cushions, however, hearing your voice is possible. The volume will depend on the headset's fit. If you have any other questions, please don't hesitate to contact Plantronics Customer Care at 800-985-9815.

I bought these last month for $118 and now for the holidays they're on sale but I couldn't wait.   Enjoy!"

answers.answer_text: it uses a USB-C so anything that will take a USB-C should work, I would imagine you just need to purchase an indian USB-C plug and you will be good to go :D
Yes compatible, you just need a power adapter

The quest will work (not sure about the app store - you may have to work through a VPN to access official games), only you will want the right charger adapter -  It is a 10W charger: output is 5.1V and 2.1A. You should be able to find something like this wherever they sell cell phones. Using an adapter from the states may not be dual-voltage (110-240v) though it's possible it can be.

Depends what the “indian power suppy“ is. U.S. standard is 60hrz/120 v AC. I WOULD check on power supply inverters to see if a power adaptor is available. If so, one question answers the other. Cautious response, call Oculus and ask....
You just need an adapter, like any other mobile phone charger.

Yes, using some data/power USB 3 cables you can use the Oculus Link feature that was just released on November 12th 2019 in Beta.  Not all have the bandwidth.  There are some limitations to supported hardware and USB cables so you'll want to check the Oculus site first.  Based on what I've seen on Youtube it works extremely well.  There can be some compression in the graphics.  Oculus will be releasing their own high quality fiber cable soon that should improve the experience and will run $79 at launch.

answers.answer_text: The Quest is a standalone gaming system, meaning the headset itself is the gaming system and contains the official App Store. The rift is PC powered, meaning you need a gaming pc capable of PCVR that you plug your headset into. The Rift is supposed to have more detailed and longer games, but you’re connected to a cord. With the Quest, you are able to play cordless (or play while charging). I don’t have a rift, but I love my Quest. It is extremely immersive and I don’t have any issues with game quality whatsoever.
The Quest has a better processor, motion tracking and a better screen (OLED vs. LCD) than the Rift.
The rift requires a high end computer to run. The quest is a stand-alone unit with no wires.

answers.answer_text: If you feel it’s too heavy or it is pressing against your face, you are not wearing it correctly. The back of your head is supposed to support most of the weight of the headset. The back strap needs to be lowered (but not too low).    Some people attach a powerbank to the backstrap using a cellphone holster or a bunch of Velcro stripes. The powerbank both can be used to charge your headset while playing, and can also serve as a counterweight.
I do not have a small face and I feel it's a bit tight. So it might be good for you.

answers.answer_text: The Oculus Quest does not support this at this time.  The Quest is a standalone VR system that does not require a PC (or Mac) to drive it.  The computer is contained in the headset itself.  There are some unsupported apps that do allow VR streaming from a PC running SteamVR if you're tech savvy enough to install and configure them (see RiftCat/Vridge and ALVR - the better option is ALVR, it is free and works best), but they're not supported by Oculus and you may not be satisfied with the results.

The built-in sound or wired earphones work perfectly.

answers.answer_text: Yes it is.  I know that you have to get another piece of hardware which would then link up to a specified device via Bluetooth.  I don’t remember what that hardware is but it’s easily available.

RIF S, will do what you described right out of the box with sound and video streaming.  I use it to stream to my large screen TV and it works just fine. Currently the Quest does not stream well out of the box. It'll stream to a phone but without sound and is laggy.  HOWEVER, With the LINK adapter (slated for release in January), the Quest is expected to work like a RIFT S, and at that point should stream with sound and video quite well to a large screen TV.
You don't need a gaming system, but yes, you can screen cast to your phone and many smart TVs to allow others to watch what you are doing and seeing in VR

answers.answer_text: With the new Oculus Link update which just came out, you are able to connect the Quest to a PC and play essentially all the same games the Rift can play, plus the Quest exclusives  as well as having the ability to simply unplug and go to a friends house or wherever you want really, and have a fun VR experience. I'd say the biggest difference now is tracking the controllers,  but it's never been a very big issue for me personally. In my opinion,  the quest is an absolute must have even if you  just like VR a little bit. On the technical side the Rift has a slightly faster refresh rate but it's almost impossible to notice,  while the Quest has better resolution. But again the difference is there but I doubt most people would notice the difference that much.
See the following page for a comparison between Rift and Quest.    https://www.oculus.com/compare/

answers.answer_text: Yes, you can! While Quest is a standalone VR headset. With a compatible PC and appropriate USB 3.0 cable, you can also use the Oculus Link feature to connect it to a PC to play Rift PC games.

The Oculus Quest is a completely wireless virtual reality headset. It doesn't need to be tethered to a PC like other powerful VR headsets and doesn't require a phone like some mobile VR devices. It features six degrees of freedom (6DoF), meaning it can track your movements up, down, left, right, forward, and backward. It doesn't require any external sensors like the original Oculus Rift or HTC Vive. Instead, it has sensors built into the headset. It also supports two updated Touch controllers, meaning it can be used to play popular gaming titles that require two hands, such as Beat Saber.    Spatial tracking from within the headset means you can move around a room-scale setup just like you can now in Rift, Vive, or Windows Mixed Reality. A camera in each corner of the headset (total of four) track space and motion controllers from the inside out. The Quest uses the same optics as the Go for a display resolution of 1,600 x 1,400 for each eye, but here you'll be able to make lens-spacing adjustments on the fly. Also, like the Go, Quest has a built-in audio system that delivers 3D sound without the need for bulky headphones. A headset jack is included if you'd like to use separate hardware, and charging is handled with a USB-C port.

answers.answer_text: If you are looking for 360 degree game immersion, the Quest has it with dual controllers and the ability to map out a safe play area. So big upgrade for gaming.
If what you are looking for is VR gaming this is like the existing PC powered headsets but without the need for the PC not wall mounts. You can literally get started in minutes. So short answer yes!

For gaming, absolutely.  The ability to move around in the VR world by moving in the real world and the ability to use both hands to grab stuff changes the entire experience for the better.  For simple movie watching it’s better in terms of screen quality.  The colors are more vivid and the image looks slightly clearer.  The only downside is that it’s a bit harder to watch movies in the dark in bed because of the way the tracking/guardian system works.  That said it’s still possible, just a bit more cumbersome than the GO.    Bottom line, I’ve owned and used both extensively. I’d pick the Quest over the GO without question.

answers.answer_text: This is a stand-alone product, and the first like this from the Oculus brand. I would encourage you to watch some youtube videos about its functionality. Games are downloaded via wifi and can be purchased or searched through the Oculus app on your smartphone.
No need to buy anything just iOS or android device for startup

Nope, the only external you need is a smartphone to connect the Quest to the Oculus App. The Quest is a fully independent console (think Nintendo Switch), games are installed via the integrated Oculus Store and played by simply selecting them in the menu.

You sign up an Oculus account online or download the Oculus app and purchase games through the website or app.  Once you download the games you link your Quest headset to you account and then the games are available to install on your headset.

Everything you need to play comes with this. It comes with the headset unit and two controllers (one for each hand). The only other thing you need is a smart phone to do the initial set up. As for the games. you purchase games from the oculus store. there is a portal to the store within the headset units main menu. you can also buy games on the oculus app on your smartphone that will be downloaded to your headset as soon as it is connected to wifi. I can recommend the purchase. I have had great luck with mine.

answers.answer_text: You download their app on your phone and purchase them there or through the headset. The games download onto the units memory, but are held in your library to download again if needed
You buy them from the online store and they are downloaded to the device. The Oculus App from the App Store shows you game prices.

It's very easy, You can purchase Oculus games either via the free  iPhone Oculus app OR directly from the VR headset. Games are stored in the headset RAM and not streamed. A few are free. Most are $19.99 to $29.99 but there is a liberal early return policy for most games if you don't like the game after you have played it a few times. I purchased the larger 128 RAM Oculus Quest.  I have downloaded 28 games and still have 85BG still free. When you purchase games via iPhone, they download when you put on the headset. I love Space Pirate Trainer, Drop Dead,  Gun Club VR, Angry Birds VR, Beat Saber, ...  I found it easy to set up and easy to use. My young grandchildren also enjoy it.  (I am 73) In fact, I bought 4 more sets for my friends and family. I have had mine since it first became available on Amazon and have had no problems except a few games like Roller Coaster and Mission:ISS were disorienting and I could not play them. Hope that helps...
You go to Occulus.com and connect your glasses (headset).  From the website you can then buy games and upload them to your headset.

You download the Oculus app, in the upper left corner is a menu to select from the Go, Quest or Rift. Games you purchase are downloaded to the headsets internal storage which is the reason they offer a 64gb and 128gb version
You may buy them on the app and through the head set. They still have to download onto your headset.

answers.answer_text: You can use the quest as a wirelessly connected computer monitor.  This requires that the quest have wifi access to a network that your computer is exposed to.  However,  there are shows I watch on cable that I can't stream to my computer and hence can't watch on quest.  It is a small list these days though as most programming is available to computer devices via one avenue or another.  The real limitation is the wifi connectivity between computer and quest.  If your computer is at home and you're at a Starbucks,  you'll need additional setup ahead of time to access your home computer via Starbucks wifi connection - that setup is do-able but is independent of the Quest.
As long as you have wifi, and there isn't too harsh of sunlight

question_text: What is the difference between the Motion UC and Jarbra Motion mono?

answers.answer_text: In my opinion, the UC is more versatile, due to the fact that it has the usb to connect to my PC.

One has a USB Bluetooth adaptor that is optimized with unified communications clients like lync and other conference call apps that run on a PC..  If your PC has Bluetooth this adaptor is usually much quicker an supports the latest Bluetooth 4.0 technologies.
I believe the difference is the mono doesn't come with the computer attachment. The UC allows you to connect to a computer and a mobile phone at the same time.

The UC stands for unified communications. Unified communications devices are used for connection to soft phones, and applications like Skype. if you are looking for a device to use a headset with your cell phone only, then a UC device is not needed. I use my UC headset with both my cell phone and connected to my computer to take calls from my clients using my company's phone system over VPN. Again, if you are not using a softphone and are only interested in a Bluetooth headset for your phone, a UC device is not needed.

Yes

With the new Xbox one controllers that have the earphone jack, yes it will. For the older controllers, you need the auxiliary adaptor that connects under the controller. No matter what, it is not completely wireless. You will always have a wire tethered from the headset to the controller. Hope this helps.

answers.answer_text: To hook up the audio from sound card you can use 3.5mm jack to RCA cable or if your sound card has optical output you can use the fiber optics cable this headset does NOT SUPPORT SPDIF digital output audio. For chat i don't know for 100% but i thing you going to need Bluetooth sound output device. I found one online for $40 and decided it's not worth it because i don't need it as bad as to spend 40 bucks. so the chat can't tell but if your PC supports Bluetooth headphones or speakers and mic i don't see why not - it should work. Headset works excellent with my XBox360 and PS3 also my TV with optical output, also same time with my android smartphone. I can pair two devices at the same time on the Bluetooth. When I don't chat i can listen to the music from my phone while playing but you can only have one stream thru Bluetooth so if you chat you can't listen to music, when there is incoming phone call chat is interrupted and vice verse. In scale from 1 o 10 suiting my needs i give 10 i have also older set Black Ops Tango, which my son is using but none of us use it on PC. I just read another post true there is small 2.5mm receptacle on the headset but I was using it only wireless. Why spend $300 (that's what i paid)and still have wires dangling from the headset, when comparable sound quality can give $80 set?
If your pc has an optical audio out then yes and u might have to purchase a 2.5mm to 3.5mm adapter for the mic.

answers.answer_text: They are actually pretty similar. The Phantom is newer and should have slightly better specifications, like the processor is much faster, but you are unlikely to notice too much difference. It may come down to which color scheme you prefer. They are both compatible with an Xbox One if you get an adapter, and with the PS4, but you need to purchase a talkback cable for the Tango while that cable comes with the Phantom. That is $17 you don't need to spend if you get the Phantom.

Same headset different look.  My personal favorite is the MW3 Delta.  The MW3 Delta has 7:1 Dolby Surround (Tango/Phantom have 5:1) and the ear cups are cloth which are a LOT more comfortable than the material used on the other headsets. Comes down to personal preference! Go to turtlebeach.com for presets and updates on any of the headsets.

Not sure about the Tangos, but I am INCREDIBLY satisfied with my Ghost Phantoms. The adjustment options make it easy to customize the headset to whatever I'm doing, and the Bluetooth syncs up with my phone so I can take calls while gaming

Sure does! Just be aware that there is a small possibility if your 3.5mm audio output jack is for audio only and not a composite audio out/mic in like in most cell phones and some laptops these days, that the output jack's pin placement could potentially be a little tight and wont align with the headphone's composite stereo + mic plug, causing the sound output to either not come out properly, or only work in one ear. That being said though, I've used these on both my of my laptops' output jacks, my external USB Audio interface's port, my old MP3 Player (all non-composite audio/mic jacks), and they've all worked fine. Added bonus they fit around the ear (entirely enclosed) and they sound great.
Yes,it works for PC computers.But can't work on PS2, PS3, Xbox 360.

bullet_point1: This Certified Refurbished product is tested and certified by the manufacturer or by a third-party refurbisher to look & work like new, with limited to no signs of wear. bullet_point2: Smart Sensor technology intuitively directs calls to phone or headset pauses music for incoming calls allows automatic answer by simply placing the headset on your ear
bullet_point3: Multi microphones optimize voice and minimize noise caused by wind movement and background sounds
bullet_point4: Tap the voice button to check battery level connection status or dial Vocalist  hear emails newsfeeds and more. Say  answer " to accept a call or  "ignore " to decline"
bullet_point5: Separate power mute and volume buttons provide easy access and control
product_description: Plantronics Voyager Legend is the newest headset in the Voyager family to deliver unsurpassed audio clarity and all day comfort. Combining triple mics that cancel noise and wind, voice commands, and Smart Sensor technology, Voyager Legend understands how and when you want to talk. Sensors react when you put the headset on, letting you quickly take a call without a click. If you're already wearing it, Voyager Legend announces who's calling and waits for you to say  answer " or  "ignore. " Simply tap the voice command button and ask to check battery level, connection status, and more. With technology this nimble, Legend is the first truly intelligent Bluetooth headset. Ideal for the mobile professional who needs wireless communications anywhere they work, the Voyager Legend can conveniently connect to your favorite mobile devices--smartphone or tablet--to ensure a seamless connection regardless of the device being used. You can also use the free MyHeadset app to display the battery meter on your Android smartphone. Offering a balanced, comfortable design, the Voyager Legend has a 25 percent smaller body size (compared to the Voyager PRO HD) and features up to 7 hours of talk time. Offering a high level of audio quality, the Voyager Legend enables you to roam into any environment with the confidence that every word will be heard clearly. The enhanced Digital Signal Processing (DSP) provides a more natural voice sound, while the wideband audio with noise cancellation capabilities enable clearer conversations over PC telephony. Finally, SoundGuard technology ensures listening comfort and acoustic limiting for protection against audio spikes. More than just taking calls on your mobile phone or tablet, the Voyager Legend also includes the A2DP Bluetooth profile, enabling you to stream music, podcasts, GPS directions, and other audio. Please Note: This product comes with 1 earbud. Does not include additional earbuds."
item_name: Plantronics 87300-41-RB Voyager Legend Wireless Bluetooth Headset - Black (Renewed)

Other than the charger I am a fan of this newer model .

product_description: Plantronics Voyager Legend is the newest headset in the Voyager family to deliver unsurpassed audio clarity and all day comfort. Combining triple mics that cancel noise and wind, voice commands, and Smart Sensor technology, Voyager Legend understands how and when you want to talk. Sensors react when you put the headset on, letting you quickly take a call without a click. If you're already wearing it, Voyager Legend announces who's calling and waits for you to say  answer " or  "ignore. " Simply tap the voice command button and ask to check battery level, connection status, and more. With technology this nimble, Legend is the first truly intelligent Bluetooth headset. Ideal for the mobile professional who needs wireless communications anywhere they work, the Voyager Legend can conveniently connect to your favorite mobile devices--smartphone or tablet--to ensure a seamless connection regardless of the device being used. You can also use the free MyHeadset app to display the battery meter on your Android smartphone. Offering a balanced, comfortable design, the Voyager Legend has a 25 percent smaller body size (compared to the Voyager PRO HD) and features up to 7 hours of talk time. Offering a high level of audio quality, the Voyager Legend enables you to roam into any environment with the confidence that every word will be heard clearly. The enhanced Digital Signal Processing (DSP) provides a more natural voice sound, while the wideband audio with noise cancellation capabilities enable clearer conversations over PC telephony. Finally, SoundGuard technology ensures listening comfort and acoustic limiting for protection against audio spikes. More than just taking calls on your mobile phone or tablet, the Voyager Legend also includes the A2DP Bluetooth profile, enabling you to stream music, podcasts, GPS directions, and other audio. Please Note: This product comes with 1 earbud. Does not include additional earbuds."
item_name: Plantronics 87300-41-RB Voyager Legend Wireless Bluetooth Headset - Black (Renewed)

Combining triple mics that cancel noise and wind, voice commands, and Smart Sensor technology, Voyager Legend understands how and when you want to talk. Sensors react when you put the headset on, letting you quickly take a call without a click. If you're already wearing it, Voyager Legend announces who's calling and waits for you to say  answer " or  "ignore. " Simply tap the voice command button and ask to check battery level, connection status, and more. With technology this nimble, Legend is the first truly intelligent Bluetooth headset. Ideal for the mobile professional who needs wireless communications anywhere they work, the Voyager Legend can conveniently connect to your favorite mobile devices--smartphone or tablet--to ensure a seamless connection regardless of the device being used. You can also use the free MyHeadset app to display the battery meter on your Android smartphone. Offering a balanced, comfortable design, the Voyager Legend has a 25 percent smaller body size (compared to the Voyager PRO HD) and features up to 7 hours of talk time. Offering a high level of audio quality, the Voyager Legend enables you to roam into any environment with the confidence that every word will be heard clearly. The enhanced Digital Signal Processing (DSP) provides a more natural voice sound, while the wideband audio with noise cancellation capabilities enable clearer conversations over PC telephony. Finally, SoundGuard technology ensures listening comfort and acoustic limiting for protection against audio spikes. More than just taking calls on your mobile phone or tablet, the Voyager Legend also includes the A2DP Bluetooth profile, enabling you to stream music, podcasts, GPS directions, and other audio. Please Note: This product comes with 1 earbud. Does not include additional earbuds."
item_name: Plantronics 87300-41-RB Voyager Legend Wireless Bluetooth Headset - Black (Renewed)

Yes.  My Samsung phone pairs automatically whenever the headset is turned on now that I paired it the first time unless my phone happens to be paired to something else via Bluetooth.  For example, I have a small bluetooth speaker unit in my kitchen that I stream music on using my phone.  If I put on my headset to go for a walk, it won't pair automatically until I get far enough away from the speaker system to drop that signal..then the phone searches and finds my headset.  The opposite happens when I return home, the phone stays connected to the headset and won't switch to the Speaker until I manually select it from my bluetooth connections menu on the phone.  I don't have to reinstall anything, just select which bluetooth device I want to use if there are ever more than one device turned on and in the room together.  If you are using this headset in your car, it works great and will definitely reconnect automatically whenever you turn it on.

To do so, power-on the headset, then press and hold the Call Button until the voice prompt  pairing " is heard, and alternating red/blue lights appear on the headset. question_text: I didn't see any battery requirements. How does the noise cancelling works? If any.
bullet_point1: Full stereo sound for crisp, clear voice and video calls
bullet_point2: Versatile noise-cancelling boom microphone lets you be clearly heard, rotates out of the way, and can be worn on the left or right side
bullet_point3: Adjustable headband and foam ear cups for a personalized, comfortable fit
bullet_point4: Convenient in-line controls let you easily adjust volume and mute the microphone
bullet_point5: Works with Windows 10 or later, Windows 8, Windows 7, or Windows Vista, Mac OS X 10.5 or later, Chrome OS, Linux Kernel 2.6+ and iOS or Android devices. Please refer the User Manual before use.
item_name: Logitech 3.5 mm Analog Stereo Headset H151 with Boom Microphone - Black

answers.answer_text: This headset does not require batteries. The headset has a 3.5 mm jack on it. All you have to do is plug it into your computer. On the headset, there are On-cord controls make it easy to quickly adjust your headset volume and mute the microphone.

The headset requires no batteries as it is wired. While the headphones themselves are not noise cancelling, the boom microphone does have noise cancelling (It picks up your voice and 'cancels' out ambient sounds that you don't intend to record).
They do not have battery  requirements.   The noise cancelling works, but you will hear outside noise.
The mic has some basic rejection  it picks up the mouth and acoustically cancels sounds coming from other directions. I would describe the mic sound as cheap, narrow, and hard.

I am not dure what you mean by battery requirements, but noise cancelling takes noise picked up through a mic hole (not the main mic) that isn't directed from the direction of you mouth and eliminates it, pretty effective, not the best.

These headphones are in no way true noise canceling headphones.  If you're looking for noise canceling headphones you can wear while cutting the lawn or while on an airplane these are not the headphones for you. The headphones do not require any batteries. I use them for a while largely for my dictation / voice recognition software and they do a good job.

answers.answer_text: These headphones have both sound output and mic in one connector.  If the laptop has separate jacks for each, then yes you'd need the right kind of splitter type thing.

There are a number of possibilities.  The most likely is you need a splitter to separate the microphone from the speaker input.  Please see the following link. https://www.amazon.com/Headphones-Convertors-Headphone-Microphone-Simultaneously/dp/B01M8G1U0C/ref pd bxgy 147 img 2/145-6185791-7463003? encoding UTF8&pd rd i B01M8G1U0C&pd rd r d98cd015-586c-4484-897a-061b407802ea&pd rd w YVui2&pd rd wg AkQUG&pf rd p 479b6a22-70ae-47a0-9700-731033f96ce8&pf rd r 1VN10QD80W0PEG7PY5F1&psc 1&refRID 1VN10QD80W0PEG7PY5F1  This should take care of the problem.

I think it only works in a socket that is able to accept headphones and a microphone on the same plug.  That's probably why it works on your phone and not your computer.  A splitter might help.  I have an HP and the socket connects to the headphones and the microphone and all is well.

Yes, you need an adapter that splits. I have always preferred analog. I'm using a USB headset now, and it's just not the same quality of sound. Even on an inexpensive headset The newer computers have either one jack, which needs a different kind of adapter, I bought this Y splitter: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00PYZ2BT4/ref ppx yo dt b asin title o04 s00?ie UTF8&psc 1   OR, analog to USB adapter, here's an option: https://www.amazon.com/Sabrent-External-Adapter-Windows-AU-MMSA/dp/B00IRVQ0F8/ref sr 1 2?keywords analog+to+usb+dongle+splitter+headset&qid 1569926706&s gateway&smid ATVPDKIKX0DER&sr 8-2  hope this helped. :)

To do so: 1) With the headset powered on, press and hold down the call control button (square button) for at least 8-10 seconds until you hear  pairing " and the headset LED starts flashing.  2) Once flashing access your phone Bluetooth settings and wait for  "PLT M70 " to come up and select it. 3)  Once successfully paired, the indicator light will stop flashing. answers.answer_text: Hello! The M70 is compatible with any device that supports Bluetooth headsets. However, as you may know, your computer is equipped with an internal Bluetooth adapter. Bluetooth technology works through several Bluetooth profiles, and these are the ones that the Bluetooth card should have to at least allow a connection to the headphones: Audio transmissions, Hands Free (HFP) and/or Headset (HSP) Bluetooth profiles. Nowadays many computers have Bluetooth built-in but not all of them support Bluetooth headsets. Many times, these drivers are not installed by default - even on new computer installations. Feel free to contact our Customer Care Team at: 800-985-9815 if you require further assistance!

Hello! We're sorry to hear this. In order to troubleshoot your earpiece, please try resetting the Bluetooth connection with your phone. To do so:  Delete the headset from your cell phone’s list of paired devices. Once deleted, power your phone completely off, then power it back on. This resets the Bluetooth stack in the Bluetooth software on the phone. Re-pair the headset with your phone. You might also want to ensure the headset is the only Bluetooth device connected to your phone while you’re using it in order to rule out wireless interference. You may also want to test it with a different phone to isolate the cause of the issue. If you still get linking issues, even after performing these tests, then most likely the unit has a problem and it is best to replace it. Please note this model has a one-year warranty from date of purchase. Feel free to contact our Customer Care Team at: 800-985-9815 if you have other questions!

Firstly, I do not like the M70...  I find it to be inferior to its other Motorola Married family members...  If you are wanting to connect 2 divices simultaneously - it sucks unless you don't care about reliability and call quality...  Secondly, I will address your question.  The M70 (as well as every Bluetooth headset for cells out there) are Class 2 devices...  It gets all of 20+/- feet depending on conditions...  FYI:  Class 3 radios - have a range of up to 1 meter or 3 feet Class 2 radios - most commonly found in mobile devices - have a range of 10 meters or 33 feet Class 1 radios - used primarily in industrial use cases - have a range of 100 meters or 300 feet
30 feet on average.

Hello, David. Yes. The M70 will stay in your ear without the over-the-ear hook due to the design of the flexible speaker cover. There is a small flange that helps stabilize the device in your ear. I hadn't considered using it in this way until your question was posed, so I just tested it without the over-the-ear hook. It stayed snug in my ear with some vigorous head movement (side to side, nodding, leaning to the side and shaking my head). The over-the-ear hook comes in handy when you are doing things that would bump the device, though. I can say that I wouldn't advocate going on a run without the over-the-ear hook. Hopefully that answers your question.

answers.answer_text: Hello! Our M70 is compatible with any device that supports Bluetooth headsets  However, please note that Bluetooth technology works through different profiles. As you know, your computer is equipped with an internal Bluetooth adapter. These are the ones that the Bluetooth card should have to at least allow a connection to the headphones: Audio transmissions, Hands Free (HFP) and/or Headset (HSP) Bluetooth profiles. Nowadays many computers have Bluetooth built-in but not all of them support Bluetooth headsets. Many times, these drivers are not installed by default   even on new computer installations. We recommend you to check out our UC line of products which are designed for mobile and PC connectivity. If you have any further questions, feel free to contact our Customer Care Team at: 800-985-9815

The primary cable out of the headset has a single complex plug.  Included with the headset is an extension cable for that complex single plug and at the other end are the two seperate plugs for headphones and mic.  So if an Xbox needs just one plug, the cable will be shorter.   This headset is discontinued and old, I'm surprised you're asking this now.

answers.answer_text: The single cable is likely for use on things like cellphones. I hadn't tried it as I intended to use it on my PC but it definitely makes sense, as there are already headsets and earbuds with mics on them for that purpose.

The 3.5mm is a single connector on each end. One end plugs into the GameOne and the other into an Xbox with a 3.5mm connector. The Xbox side is a 4 pole and handles both mic and earphones. The split 3.5mm has two connectors on the Xbox controller side. This is for devices that have separate connectors for mic and earphones like a laptop.

answers.answer_text: This set is my second set of Sennheisers.  I find them to be extremely comfortable, even if you need (or want) to wear them all day long (seriously).  I actually used my first set of Sennheiser headphones for over 5 years before purchasing this G4ME ONE set.  I needed the boom mic for playing Elite: Dangerous, and the pad that cushions the top of the head was actually beginning to disintegrate due to how much I used them.  I have to say that the Sennheiser ear cups are very spacious, comfortable, the velour-like material that covers the ear pads eliminates uncomfortable ear sweating, and they sound amazing.  My previous set of Sennheiser headphones (think they were PXC 350 model?) were more than twice what these cost, but I think the G4ME ONE set actually sounds better.  I also like the way they put the volume control in the right ear phone instead of being an inline control on the cord (those always wear out and get noisy).  I really couldn't be more pleased with them.  In another 5 years, once I literally wear these out, I'll purchase another pair of Sennheisers in this same form factor.
My ears are big but they fit inside so there is no pressure on them.

Old question but it is still top 5. I have a pair of ATH m50x's as well and was disappointed by the pain they caused after a half an hour (my sensitive ears.) I brought a HD 598 in Dec 2014 and they were and still are perfect. I would recommend these cans if they use the same pads as the HD 598, which they sort of look like they do.

I have big ears. I can wear these for a few hours before they start getting uncomfortable. After that my ears start to get a little sore. These are the only over the ear headphones I've ever tried that I can wear more then 15 min.

Just got these for Christmas. I guess I have an even bigger head/ears than previous answering owners because I'm going to have to return these. My ears hurt horribly after 2 hours. Very disappointed they aren't comfortable for prolonged use as I'm impressed with them in all other regards. As a point of comparison, I have a pair of Bose QC25 that I wear for 10+ hours a day at work with no discomfort.

I have the ATH M50Xs and they are extremely uncomfortable for long periods of time. That being said, I have had both the GAME ONE headset and the GAME ZERO headset and the GAME ZERO is more comfortable. They are both comfortable, but the GAME ZERO is just a more comfortable and if you are looking to wear them for more than an hour, you will be quite pleased.
I literally came here because my ears are currently soar from it gamng all day with my m50x’s. Can somebody actually confirm that the eat cups are deeper???

M50x earpads are significantly smaller than the HD 598/GAME ONE pads, you’ll have more room for your ears with the GAME series. Game Zero are the same form factor, but closed back (like ear muffs) and pleather pads.    I don’t know if you’re using the pleather or velour pads with your ATH, but I tend to feel leather, protein leather, or pleather (plastic leather) all seem to feel harder the longer you wear them, plus they build up sweat. I personally prefer Velour by a long shot, and Sennheiser’s velour is softer and not prickly/itchy like many other brands’ Velour. That said, some people just feel more comfortable with Leather(ette), or like that leather(ette) is more durable/easier to clean, in which case Dekoni Audio makes the softest leatherette I’ve ever felt specifically for the Game One/PC37X.

I have a gigantic melon (size 8 fitted hats fit snug) and these are very comfortable.  Although my ears are not like dumbo, they are proportionate to my enormous gourd and I have no issues with these awesome cans!

No.  The audio adapter is only needed if you have a triple insulated 3.5mm jack (three black rings).  Most computers will have two 3.5mm jacks.  One for the audio in (usually pink), and one for the audio out (usually green).  If you have both of these you will not need the audio adapter.

answers.answer_text: Umm. You want to connect two Game One headphones to one motherboard? I don't think that's possible. What you can get is a sound splitter. Im the exact opposite of everyone else that has replied to you. I have Astro A40's on right now and although the sound and mic quality are good (not fantastic), the ear cup padding is lacking. It's made out of a strange fabric that is mildy uncomfortable after about ten minutes. It's not horrible but it can be distracting at times. That aside however, I really like the A40. Im thinking about using these for my xbox and A40 for pc because of the mix amp and 5000 feet of chords.

Unfortunately, the Astro A40s are about the only headset that I haven't tried. While I have heard good things about the Astros, I'd be shocked if the mic on the Astros are as good as the mic on the G4ME ONE. As far as sound quality, that is subjective, as what sound good to one person may not sound as good to another. For example some people like music that is colored by the speakers with added bass for instance. I on the other hand prefer my speakers to be extremely accurate and portray music and sound the way the artist intended for you to hear it.  That's why I went with the G4ME ONE as the sound is very accurate! In addition, as Mack Isgro alluded to in this thread, I too absolutely love the spatial stage or dimension the G4ME ONE gives you due to its open acoustic nature. I can't tell you the amount of times I've heard something and turned my head to look over my shoulder or have been freaked out by the sound I was hearing...and that's about the best compliment I can give for a headset -- that it immerses you in the music/sounds and makes you lose yourself in the world you're playing in.  So, while I can't speak for the Astros as I have not heard them, I can tell you that the G4ME ONE is a fantastic headset IMHO.  One last thing to consider though is that the G4ME ONE likes a bit of juice to sound its best. So, if you are not planning to purchase a separate amp for the G4ME ONE, you might want to consider the Astros, which I believe can be purchased as a package with an amp. Just food for thought.  Hope that helps! :)
Sennheiser 100%

No, these are normal analog (that is, this uses a 1/8  stereo headphone plug and a 1/8 " mic plug, not a USB cable) headphones.  My suggestion would be to get these or some other high-quality stereo headphones, then install a program like Razer's  "Synapse Surround " for Windows to provide you with the positional surround you are looking for from 3D games or 5.1/7.1ch movie surround sound.  I recently tried out the Razer surround program in the game Killing Floor 2, and closing my eyes with a cheap Logitech headset on I was able to point my character toward approaching enemies solely by ear.  I couldn't believe it, but it completely convinced me that it would be better to buy a pair of headphones with two excellent drivers than a set with ten individual drivers that were lower-quality for the same price."

Short answer is no BUT Sennheiser released the 3DM1 USB Adaptor in April 2016. This USB 2.0 adapter, called a  sound card " by Sennheiser, provides 7.1 simulated surround at DVD quality for around  $50, and is now a selectable option in your ordering for this headphone as well as a number of other Sennheiser gaming headphones. Here is the Amazon link to the stand-alone product if you wanted to purchase separately https://www.amazon.com/Sennheiser-Adaptor-Gaming-Headsets-3DM1/dp/B01ER49SCA/ref cm cd al qh dp t"
They're stereo headphones, no surround sound adapter.
No, they are only stereo. Your sound card may be able to simulate surround, but the headset itself does not simulate surround.

I have mostly used these when raiding in Destiny 2. I’ve had family members come in to my room while I was playing and they could talk to me with the headset on and I could hear them just fine. The sound that comes through the headset has more of the effect of speakers in a room rather than traditional headphones in that sense. With normal headphones it’s like cupping your hands over your ears and then playing music under your hands. All you hear is quiet and the music. With these, If your game is playing you can hear it in you ears really well but it’s not blocking much of anything else out. That’s kind of the point of open backed earphones though. The sound feels like it’s coming from the whole room rather than just a cup over your ears so the sound stage seems much larger.

The other cable is the same only it is just a 3.5 headphone jack on one end and the proprietary connector on the other.
The single cord comes standard as a 2x3.5mm.

Simply click buy and wait for their velvety sweetness to arrive at your doorstep.
You need an amp to use this headset. My friend uses his with a creative sound card with an amp built in. Without an amp you cannot hear anything.

These headphones sound good without an amp... But they sound GREAT with one. I use them with my cell phone, tablet, Xbox One, and PC. My PC is the only device that has an amp. Again, awesome on the PC (because of the amp), good on everything else.

answers.answer_text: https://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-reviews/R9NIJH14JVS89/ref cm cr getr d rvw ttl?ie UTF8&ASIN B00KK8ZLEC

Umm.. depends...on you actually... These headphones are capable of giving really really crisp sound. so on stereo mode, you can more easily make out footsteps. So it's not bad. But I have the GSX 1000 Senheiser AMP which offers 7.1 surround sound and I think coupled with that it has the  best surround sound in gaming. It also depends on what headsets you're talking about. The ONLY HEADSETS i would say have  good surround sound " are the Hyper X Cloud 2 and the Logitech G933. Some surround sounds may make footsteps harder to hear but these two are good alternatives. I prefer playing in surround sound on all my headsets including the Game Ones. Competitive gamers say it's better to play at stereo 2.0 so if you play stereo and agree with them, this headset will be the best stereo you can get.     My conclusion: it depends on how you perceive sound. I prefer 7.1 surround sound over Stereo for single player AND multiplayer gaming. These headphones ARE 2.0 stereo BUT if you have an MSI motherboard like the Gaming M5, you can add virtual surround sound just like any other headphones and you'll note it sounds better. Better yet, if you buy a sound blaster z sound card you can add virtual surround sound too. If money is an issue grab the Hyper X Cloud II's. You can watch reviews of it online it's an amazing headset with clear crisp sound. Best sound for gaming headset obv comes from these but because it is a 3.5mm jack connector, it depends on your hardware as well."

It all depends on what you're looking for in your headset. 7.1 surround sound is good at simulating directional sound for things like videos and movies and the like, but stereo sound is much better for proper directional input, like for gaming (Tested with Rainbow Six: Siege for demonstration). Hope this helps!
Yes

Honestly, you don't really need 7.1 surround sound for gaming, stereo sounds just fine. If you have a sound card that supports 7.1 surround sound then you can just use that, but to me, it sounds really weird and distorted. I've been using these headphones for about a month now on stereo mode and I can hear every little detail in-game with crystal clarity.     However, at the end of the day, it's all about what sounds good to you. I personally think stereo sounds much better than 7.1 sound, but I suggest trying out other sound options to see what works for your ears.

answers.answer_text: 5 or 6 feet, sorry not near them. Yes both mic and headphone jacks, plus another shorter cord with both on 1 jack

There are 2 cables provided with the headset.  First is a combo 3.5mm jack (that combines the mic and speaker into a single jack for use with cell phones) which is 1.2 meters (3.93 feet) long.  Second is dual 3.5mm jacks, one for mic one for speaker which measures 3 meters (9.84252 feet) long.  Enjoy them if you buy them!

The cable measures 10 feet long, so it will be plenty long enough for use on any computer system with no extension needed.  I forgot about the single connector cable for use on phones etc. because I specifically bought the headset for use on my computer. That cable is about five feet or so. My apologies for missing that originally!

answers.answer_text: Good day, and thank you for your question. From a technical standpoint  side tone " degrades audio quality as it is creating extra noise in the ear piece that is competing with the audio of the conversation so Sennheiser deliberately builds gaming headsets to not product  "side tone ".   In a high quality headset there is a headphone signal and a mic signal that are not mixed at all and hence  "side tone " doesn't occur in the headset. The mixing of these signals is done at the source or console, so ultimately the Xbox 1 would be responsible for providing side-tone. To create  "side tone " a user would use the settings on the console to make adjustments and deliberately feed the create  "side tone ". According to online threads, you can make this happen in the xBox settings. Hopefully this helps, and have a good afternoon"

answers.answer_text: This doesn't sound likely as this headset can easily be powered by an xbox controller so I don't understand the need for power amplification.

It really depends on whether you want more sound out of these headphones. If you are into heavy bass then it will boost the bass on the settings you set it at. I am no means an expert in sound but I tested these headsets with creative labs G5 dac and the difference is great. I can hear an enormous amount of bass pumping through the cans of these headset. The dac comes pre-configured with different modes that you can set it at, (i.e. Movie, music, witcher 3, mgsv, league of legends, and genre). In my opinion, if you want insane bass then go for the dac because it will settle nicely with these headphones. If you don't need bass then just forget about it. There are other factors to consider such as mids/highs and what not  but I'm no expert at differentiating these sounds so I base it off of my sole opinion in bass. If you do get the particular model dac I have then be wary that there are many negative experiences with this dac. I've read that the card burns out in a couple months after usage. Unfortunately, I cannot comment on long term usage since I just bought it two weeks ago. So far the dac is what I use everyday. I would recommend researching more into dac since they are pricey and run up anywhere from $100-300. Good luck!

answers.answer_text: its always on, but most of the time the choice to ptt is through the program you are using.  If you want to mute, just lift the mic up.

The mic is designed in a way that as soon as you push down the mic in front of your face to talk, it will turn on. When you're not using the mic, pull it back up and it will automatically turn off with a 'click' sound. I think it's a pretty neat design.
its always on unless you have it pointed up then it is just muted. but if you use a program that has a push to talk feature then its able to work that way.

It comes down to what voice software you are using. The software determines whether or not you want to use Push to talk (PTT) or Open mic. I use Open mic since there is noise cancellation on these gaming head set.
Microphone is always on when in down position by your mouth and mutes when you raise it up.  Push to talk would be configured through any game you're playing.

It's always on if you have it flipped down unless you set it up otherwise in game. If you have it flipped up it remains off, which is just how I use it. I'm told by people who I game with though that it's not picking up on my breathing or anything like that if you are wondering.
There is no talk switch on the microphone.  Activating a ptt function can be done via your communications software via voice actuation, or a programmed keyboard switch.

I have never used hd 598.  I have used mod Mics and my ocd cannot Handle it.  I can tell you the game ones are amazing.  People say my voice is more clear now and the audio quality is hard(if not impossible to to beat for a gaming headset. I have both. In terms of sound quality, the game GAME ONEs sound good, but the 598s have a noticeably richer sound. I feel that the GAME ONEs sound a bit flat in comparison (though I'm sure they are far better than typical gaming head sets). The 598s are much more comfortable for people with a larger head. For me the GAME ONEs are a bit tight. I could wear the 598s for many hours without any discomfort, while the GAME ONEs put some pressure on my temples. Haven't had the need to add a mic to the 598s so can't compare that. The cable is detachable on both sets. The 598s come with a 1/4  jack + adapter to 3.5mm, while the GAME ONEs come with 3.5mm single and split cables."

I have had both and while the Mod-Mic solves the problem of not being able to use your favorite pair of headphones for gaming, having to fumble with an extra cord (the one connected to the Mod-Mic) and having to constantly untangle the two cords, I say just get the G4ME ONE and be done with it.  The mic on the G4ME ONE is excellent and the flip up mute is an ingenious design.  As far as sound quality is concerned, the G4ME ONE drivers are every bit as good as the 598's.  Don't buy into the non-sense that a gaming headset cannot match a pair of headphones in sound quality.

answers.answer_text: No. You'll want to check out the Sennheiser PC 333D.  It has 7.1 virtual surround sound.

No, it does not have surround sound. However, it's audio reproduction is said to be more accurate than most other headsets. And if you are thinking of using this for games like CS:GO, or any other game where you need to hear footsteps, this headset does that perfectly fine. I find myself hearing footsteps that no one else in my game can hear all the time.

This isn't a surround sound headset, it actually offers about the best pure sound in a gaming headset though besides like a 4-500 dollar set like the Beyer Dynamic. Pure stereo headsets are better than the gimmicky virtual surround sets. You can get virtual surround through a sound card like the creative SoundBlasterZ, or you can use the Razer virtual surround software (inferior) for free.  Regardless, for these headphones you really need an amp to drive them either through a dedicated sound card or a separate headphone amp. I use the Creative SoundblasterZ and these cans sound fantastic, and yes in games like CSGO I can clearly pinpoint where the enemy is from footsteps using the virtual surround, and it's perfectly crisp, loud and clear.

This headset is 2.4ghz. The same frequency as many other wireless things such as controllers, some remotes, wireless home phones, etc. Many wireless routers are 2.4ghz too. Pros: Sound quality is AWESOME.  Input is outstanding, does not feel like you are having to yell.  The Audio Boost features actually work. (There are buttons on the device that actually boost bass features) Price is phenomenal for what you get.  Battery life is actually decent.   Cons: (After having them for a couple of months)  Biggest Problem right now, I just broke the slider part on the left side of the headset. I put a little to much presure on where the headset flexes and the arm split. NOW, I have yet to talk with Turtle Beach about replacing them, but this is not my first run in with replacing Turtle Beach Headsets. (X11's I had to send in because the chord had pulled out of the controller (The thing with the mute feature and volume control) When I sent those back they replaced them no charge. EXCELLENT Customer Service.  -The Device uses one of your usb slots on the front of the device. Not really a problem for most, but I bought that stupid Nykon charger which uses BOTH front slots to charge the devices.. .   Overall, these phones are great. Even though mine just split, I would recommend them still. I have two headsets that I use regularly and this is the better of the two. (Other being the HyperX, which is the same price)

answers.answer_text: It seems to depend on the battery remaining - if it's at full charge, I can go about 12 feet, but if it's at low charge, I need to be much closer.  From similar headphones I've owned, it also can depend majorly on the the wifi hotspots nearby. If there's just one router nearby, they've had better signal and range. If there are dozens, performance can be affected.

I've searched my manual for the 'official' range but can't find any info there. On a full charge I've been as far away as 30'-35' with no significant loss in audio quality. I'd think they'd get somewhat better than that as an outside range but can't say from experience.  Hope this helps establish at least a minimal standard to work with, sorry I can't be more help. Good luck!

question_text: What is the difference in stereo and surround sound?
bullet_point1: 100% Wireless   Experience crystal clear, interference-free game and chat audio with 100% wireless connectivity to your PS4 Pro, PS4, and PS3.
bullet_point2: EQ Audio Presets   Enhance your gameplay experience with EQ presets including Bass Boost

item_name: Turtle Beach - Ear Force Stealth 400 Fully Wireless Gaming Headset - PS4 (Discontinued by Manufacturer)

answers.answer_text: Stereo sound comes from 2.1 speakers meaning there's 2 speakers and a dedicated bass thing. Surroud usually means 7.1 which has 7 individual speakers in each earcup giving it the sense that the sound is comming from all around you. That same effect is sometimes achieved through software.

Surround sound gives you both a more immersive audio experience and more accurate positional sound. For example, when a bullet whizzes past you in a game like Battlefront you can tell which direction it came from and here it move past you. Stereo sound is still perfectly good, but once you experience surround sound it is hard to go back to stereo. Surround sound in headsets with two speaker drivers is achieved using advanced digital signal processing. It is very accurate, and sounds better and is more accurate than a typical consumer-grade multi-speaker home theater set-up. If you read some of the reviews of our new headsets that use DTS Headphone:X surround sound the writers do a good job of explaining how good it sounds. Both the Elite 800 and Stealth 500P offer DTS surround sound for the PS4. Really good surround sound requires digital audio, so the wireless transmitter connects to the optical port at the back of the PS4.

answers.answer_text: Ignore the answer from Davina. I've actually used both headsets a ton and the Stealth 400 is better in the most important ways: 1- battery life. Stealth gets you about 16 hours on a charge. Gold gets you about 7 if you're lucky. 2- sound. The audio produced by the Stealth is light years ahead of what the Gold produces 3- maximum volume. Again, the Stealth produces a much louder experience if you want it 4- microphone. People have a hard time hearing me at times on the Golds. Never on the Stealth 5- build quality. Both are cheaply made, but the Golds have a design flaw that will ensure that all units break eventually. The hinges are cheap plastic that wear down every single time you fold them. If you have a pair, look at the 4 little hinges right now and I guarantee you'll see cracks forming in the middle of all 4. Once one of them breaks, you either need to get some strong tape to hold it together or buy a new pair.

I prefer the look and feel of the turtle beach headphones.  The sound quality is great and they are extremely comfortable.  I can wear them for long hours and they don't hurt my head or cause my ears to get hot.  I also chose these for the placement of the controls and the mic.

I would go with the PS Gold. I bought a pair of these used and the mic didn't work. My friend however has a pair and they work great. I like the PS Gold headphones a lot but they could be a bit louder.

I would say prices are different. Turtle Beach has some attachments were you can use your phone with apps, music, and phone calls. The PS ones say you need and app to use different headset settings. Everything is on the Turtle Beach ones. It's your money spend it how you wish.
The only good thing about this turtle beach is the battery life and that's all.

Honestly I don't know because I never had the playstation gold head set so I wouldn't be able to compare the two headsets but I did have the PS3 stereo version of the gold and it was a great headset so either way if you get the gold headset or the stealth 400 headset your still getting a good headset. I also wanted to get the gold headset but I got a deal with the stealth 400 at $79.99 so I couldn't pass it up and I also wanted to get the Hyper X Cloud 2 if you want just read the descriptions on all 3 headsets and see which ones you like best... Good luck

You unplug the handset from the phone, plug the box into the phone then the handset into the box.  So you can still use the headset or the original handset.  As long as you have a normal coiled handset chord it should work.

answers.answer_text: Hi JTL,    That will depend on whether your use a lifter or a hookswitch with your LH270. It will also depend on your phone make and model, since that will determine if your phone is compatible with a lifter or a hookswitch. Without either of those accessories, the LH270 will still work, but you won't be able to answer and hang up on calls just by pressing the power button on your headset.
